title: Epic 7: Fix Broken Links and Content Issues
description:
## Summary
Resolve all broken links and content issues identified during the documentation audit. This includes GitBook orphan page references, absolute GitBook editor URLs, and anchor ID mismatches.

## Context
During the audit of the 17 GitBook Markdown files, 6 broken links were identified. These fall into 3 categories:

### Category 1: GitBook Orphan Page References (3 instances)
When GitBook exports/syncs to Git, internal cross-references that fail to resolve become `/broken/pages/XXXXX` links. These need to be either resolved to the correct page or removed.

| File | Broken Link | Line Context |
|---|---|---|
| `README.md` (line 47) | `/broken/pages/gNQzZ9R1b3NKrJoQ0Iqa` | Appears in the welcome page content |
| `lexicons/introduction-to-lexicons.md` (line 11) | `/broken/pages/3UwgsMpD20ErXurhzmTh` | Appears in introductory text about lexicons |
| `lexicons/introduction-to-lexicons.md` (line 13) | `/broken/pages/FdVczwFhTBj7n5nszh0P` | Appears in introductory text about lexicons |

**Resolution approach:** Read the surrounding text to infer what the link was supposed to point to. If the target can be determined (e.g., it was linking to another page in the docs), update the link. If not determinable, remove the link and leave the text as plain text, optionally adding a TODO comment.

### Category 2: Absolute GitBook Editor URL (1 instance)
| File | Broken Link |
|---|---|
| `lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/activity-claim.md` | `https://app.gitbook.com/o/uxU8o4s6mrp88yBisLn5/s/8dkOAon1uQbyqL8RomaJ/hypercert-claim-lexicons/the-impact-and-work-space` |

**Resolution:** Replace with a relative link to `/getting-started/the-impact-and-work-space` (the equivalent page in the new site structure).

### Category 3: Anchor ID Mismatches (2 instances)
| File | Link | Problem |
|---|---|---|
| `getting-started/the-impact-and-work-space.md` | `the-impact-and-work-space.md#the-impact-space` | The heading `#the-impact-space` does not exist in the file. Need to check what heading was intended and fix the anchor. |
| `lexicons/general-lexicons/location.md` | `location.md#locationtype` | The heading is `### Location Type` which generates anchor `#location-type` (with hyphen), not `#locationtype`. Fix to `#location-type`. |

## Acceptance Criteria
- All 3 `/broken/pages/...` links are either resolved to correct targets or removed with surrounding text cleaned up
- The absolute GitBook editor URL in activity-claim.md is replaced with a relative link
- Both anchor mismatches are fixed to point to valid heading IDs
- No broken internal links remain (verify by searching for `/broken/pages`, `app.gitbook.com`, and testing all internal anchor links)
- A grep for `/broken/` across all files returns zero results
- A grep for `app.gitbook.com` across all content files returns zero results

title: Epic 4: Navigation and Layout System
description:
## Summary
Replace GitBook's SUMMARY.md-based navigation with a programmatic sidebar and page layout system built in React. This includes the sidebar navigation, page layout chrome, and previous/next pagination.

## Context
GitBook uses a file called SUMMARY.md to define the table of contents. It uses a nested Markdown list format:
```markdown
# Table of contents
* [Welcome to the Hypercerts Protocol](README.md)
## Getting Started
* [Why we're building Hypercerts](getting-started/why-were-building-hypercerts.md)
...
## Lexicons
* [Introduction to Lexicons](lexicons/introduction-to-lexicons.md)
* [General Lexicons](lexicons/general-lexicons/README.md)
  * [Shared Defs](lexicons/general-lexicons/shared-defs.md)
...
---
* [Deep Dive: The Work Scope](deep-dive-the-work-scope.md)
```

This must be replaced with:
1. A JavaScript/JSON navigation config
2. A Sidebar React component
3. A Layout React component wrapping all pages via _app.js

## Navigation Structure to Implement
```js
const navigation = [
  { title: 'Welcome', path: '/' },
  {
    title: 'Getting Started',
    children: [
      { title: 'Why we\'re building Hypercerts', path: '/getting-started/why-were-building-hypercerts' },
      { title: 'Introduction to Impact Claims', path: '/getting-started/introduction-to-impact-claims' },
      { title: 'The Impact and Work Space', path: '/getting-started/the-impact-and-work-space' },
      { title: 'The Hypercerts Infrastructure', path: '/getting-started/the-hypercerts-infrastructure' },
      { title: 'Installing the SDK', path: '/getting-started/installing-the-sdk' },
    ]
  },
  {
    title: 'Lexicons',
    children: [
      { title: 'Introduction to Lexicons', path: '/lexicons/introduction-to-lexicons' },
      { title: 'General Lexicons', path: '/lexicons/general-lexicons',
        children: [
          { title: 'Shared Defs', path: '/lexicons/general-lexicons/shared-defs' },
          { title: 'Location', path: '/lexicons/general-lexicons/location' },
        ]
      },
      { title: 'Hypercerts Lexicons', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons',
        children: [
          { title: 'Activity Claim', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/activity-claim' },
          { title: 'Contribution', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/contribution' },
          { title: 'Evaluation', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/evaluation' },
          { title: 'Measurement', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/measurement' },
          { title: 'Evidence', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/attachment' },
          { title: 'Rights', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/rights' },
          { title: 'Collection', path: '/lexicons/hypercerts-lexicons/collection' },
        ]
      }
    ]
  },
  { title: 'Deep Dive: The Work Scope', path: '/deep-dive-the-work-scope' },
];
```

## Required Components
1. **navigation.js** - Config file defining the nav tree above
2. **components/Sidebar.js** - Recursive sidebar renderer with: active page highlighting, collapsible sections, section headers for 'Getting Started' / 'Lexicons'
3. **components/Layout.js** - Page chrome: header with site title, sidebar, main content area, prev/next pagination at bottom
4. **pages/_app.js** - Wraps all pages in the Layout component, passes pageProps.markdoc.frontmatter to Layout
5. **components/TableOfContents.js** (optional) - Right-side outline generated from heading nodes on the current page

## Acceptance Criteria
- Sidebar renders the full navigation tree matching the current SUMMARY.md structure
- Current page is highlighted in sidebar
- Sections are collapsible
- Prev/next pagination works at the bottom of each page
- Layout is responsive (sidebar collapses on mobile)
- Page title from frontmatter is displayed
- SUMMARY.md can be deleted after this is complete

title: Epic 1: Scaffold Next.js + Markdoc Project
description:
## Summary
Set up the Next.js project with Markdoc integration inside the existing documentation/ directory. This is the foundation that all other migration work depends on.

## Context
The current documentation is a GitBook-managed site (17 Markdown files, no package.json, no build toolchain). It needs to be restructured into a Next.js + Markdoc project that can be deployed to Vercel.

## Acceptance Criteria
- package.json exists with next, react, react-dom, @markdoc/markdoc, @markdoc/next.js as dependencies
- next.config.js exists with withMarkdoc({ mode: 'static' }) and pageExtensions: ['md', 'mdoc', 'js', 'jsx', 'ts', 'tsx']
- Directory structure has: pages/, components/, markdoc/, public/, styles/ directories
- pages/_app.js exists with a basic Layout wrapper
- npm run dev starts the dev server successfully
- npm run build completes without errors
- .gitignore includes node_modules/, .next/, out/

title: Epic 6: Images and Asset Migration
description:
## Summary
Move all image assets from the GitBook-specific `.gitbook/assets/` directory to the standard Next.js `public/images/` directory, rename files to remove spaces, update all references in content files, and delete the old `.gitbook/` directory.

## Context
The current documentation stores 2 PNG images in `documentation/.gitbook/assets/`:
- `hypercerts_for_projects.png` (referenced in README.md)
- `hypercert erd.png` (referenced in README.md and getting-started/introduction-to-impact-claims.md)

In the Next.js + Markdoc setup, static assets live in the `public/` directory and are served from the root URL path. For example, `public/images/foo.png` is accessible at `/images/foo.png`.

The filename `hypercert erd.png` contains a space which causes issues with URLs and tooling. It must be renamed.

## Tasks

### 1. Create the public/images/ directory
```bash
mkdir -p documentation/public/images
```

### 2. Copy and rename image files
```bash
cp 'documentation/.gitbook/assets/hypercerts_for_projects.png' documentation/public/images/hypercerts_for_projects.png
cp 'documentation/.gitbook/assets/hypercert erd.png' documentation/public/images/hypercert-erd.png
```
Note: `hypercert erd.png` is renamed to `hypercert-erd.png` (space replaced with hyphen).

### 3. Update image references in content files
These files reference the images (they may already be converted to Markdoc `{% figure %}` tags by Epic 3):

**pages/index.md** (was README.md) - 2 references:
- `.gitbook/assets/hypercerts_for_projects.png` -> `/images/hypercerts_for_projects.png`
- `.gitbook/assets/hypercert erd.png` -> `/images/hypercert-erd.png`

**pages/getting-started/introduction-to-impact-claims.md** - 1 reference:
- `../.gitbook/assets/hypercert erd.png` -> `/images/hypercert-erd.png`

### 4. Delete the .gitbook/ directory
```bash
rm -rf documentation/.gitbook
```

### 5. Verify
- Confirm `public/images/` contains both PNGs
- Confirm no remaining references to `.gitbook/` in any content files
- Confirm images render correctly in the dev server

## Acceptance Criteria
- `documentation/public/images/hypercerts_for_projects.png` exists
- `documentation/public/images/hypercert-erd.png` exists (no space in filename)
- All 3 image references across 2 files point to `/images/...` paths
- `documentation/.gitbook/` directory is deleted
- No file in the project references `.gitbook/` anymore
- Images render correctly when viewing pages in the browser

title: Epic 8: Build Configuration and Vercel Deployment
description:
## Summary
Configure the Next.js build pipeline, verify it works end-to-end, and set up Vercel deployment for the documentation site.

## Context
After Epics 1-7, the documentation site should be a fully functional Next.js + Markdoc project in the `documentation/` directory. This epic ensures the build actually works and the site can be deployed.

## Tasks

### 1. Verify Local Development Server
```bash
cd documentation
npm run dev
```
- Open http://localhost:3000 in a browser
- Navigate through all pages and verify they render correctly
- Check that images load, tables render, callouts display, columns layout works
- Fix any runtime errors or warnings in the console

### 2. Verify Production Build
```bash
cd documentation
npm run build
```
- Ensure the build completes with zero errors
- Fix any build-time errors (missing imports, type errors, invalid Markdoc syntax, etc.)

### 3. Test Production Server Locally
```bash
cd documentation
npm run start
```
- Verify the production build serves correctly
- Spot-check pages for rendering issues

### 4. Configure Static Export (Optional)
If pure static hosting is desired, add to next.config.js:
```js
module.exports = withMarkdoc({ mode: 'static' })({
  output: 'export',
  pageExtensions: ['md', 'mdoc', 'js', 'jsx', 'ts', 'tsx']
});
```
Then run `npm run build` which will output to the `out/` directory.

### 5. Set Up Vercel Deployment
- Connect the GitHub repository to Vercel (https://vercel.com/new)
- Configure project settings:
  - **Root Directory:** `documentation`
  - **Framework Preset:** Next.js
  - **Build Command:** `npm run build` (or auto-detected)
  - **Output Directory:** `.next` (or `out` if using static export)
- Deploy and verify the live site works

### 6. Update .gitignore
Ensure these entries exist in `documentation/.gitignore`:
```
node_modules/
.next/
out/
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- `npm run dev` starts without errors and all pages render correctly
- `npm run build` completes with zero errors
- `npm run start` serves the production build correctly
- .gitignore excludes node_modules/, .next/, out/
- Vercel deployment is configured and the site is accessible at a Vercel URL
- All pages, images, tables, callouts, and navigation work on the deployed site

title: Epic 3: Content Migration - Convert All 17 Markdown Files
description:

title: Epic 9: Cleanup and Verification
description:
## Summary
Final cleanup pass to remove all GitBook artifacts, verify link integrity, and perform visual QA against the original GitBook rendering. This is the last step before the migration is considered complete.

## Context
After Epics 1-8, the documentation site has been scaffolded, content migrated, styled, and deployed. This epic handles the final housekeeping to ensure nothing was missed and the migration is clean.

## Tasks

### 1. Remove GitBook Artifacts
Delete all files and directories that are GitBook-specific and no longer needed:

- `documentation/.gitbook/` directory (should already be deleted in Epic 6, verify)
- `documentation/SUMMARY.md` (replaced by programmatic navigation in Epic 4)
- Any remaining GitBook-specific frontmatter in content files (the `layout:` block with `width`, `visible` settings, and `metaLinks.alternates` pointing to `app.gitbook.com`)

### 2. Run a Link Checker
Search all content files for broken links:
```bash
# Check for GitBook artifacts
grep -r '/broken/pages/' documentation/pages/
grep -r 'app.gitbook.com' documentation/pages/
grep -r '.gitbook/' documentation/pages/
grep -r ' ' documentation/pages/
grep -rP '\x{200b}' documentation/pages/   # zero-width spaces

# Check for orphaned anchor references
# Verify all internal links resolve to actual pages
```

Consider using a link-checking tool like `broken-link-checker` or the Next.js build output to identify 404s.

### 3. Visual QA
For each of the 17 pages, compare the Markdoc-rendered version against the original GitBook rendering (if still accessible at the GitBook URL). Check:
- Text content matches (no missing paragraphs, headings, or list items)
- Tables render with correct data and proper headers
- Callout/hint boxes display correctly with appropriate styling
- Column layouts work (side-by-side on desktop, stacked on mobile)
- Images display and are correctly sized
- Code blocks render with proper formatting
- Internal navigation links work (sidebar, in-page links, prev/next)

### 4. Verify Heading Anchor IDs
Markdoc auto-generates heading IDs from heading text. Verify that:
- Any in-page anchor links (e.g., `#location-type`, `#the-impact-space`) correctly match the auto-generated IDs
- The heading ID generation is consistent (lowercase, hyphens for spaces, special chars stripped)

### 5. Final File Inventory
Confirm the final project structure matches expectations:
```
documentation/
├── components/          # React components
├── markdoc/             # Tag/node definitions
├── pages/               # All 17 content files as .md + _app.js
├── public/images/       # 2 PNG files
├── styles/              # CSS
├── next.config.js
├── package.json
├── package-lock.json
└── .gitignore
```

No `.gitbook/`, no `SUMMARY.md`, no files outside the standard Next.js structure.

### 6. Update README or Add a Project README
Optionally create a top-level README.md (at the repo root, not in pages/) explaining:
- How to run the docs locally (`npm install && npm run dev`)
- How the project is structured
- How to add new pages
- How Markdoc tags work

## Acceptance Criteria
- Zero grep hits for `/broken/pages/`, `app.gitbook.com`, `.gitbook/`, ` `, zero-width spaces in content files
- `SUMMARY.md` is deleted
- `.gitbook/` directory is deleted
- All 17 pages render correctly in the browser with no visual regressions
- All internal links resolve correctly (no 404s)
- All heading anchor links work
- The project directory structure is clean (no orphaned files)
- `npm run build` still succeeds after cleanup

title: Epic 2: Build Custom Markdoc Tags and React Components
description: ## Summary Create custom Markdoc tag definitions and corresponding React components to replace all GitBook-proprietary syntax. These tags will be used when converting content files in later phases. ## Context The GitBook documentation uses these proprietary tags/syntax that have no standard Markdown equivalent: 1. `{% columns %}` / `{% column %}` / `{% endcolumn %}` / `{% endcolumns %}` - Multi-column layout (used in README.md, 2 column pairs) 2. `{% hint style="info" %}` / `{% endhint %}` - Admonition/callout boxes (used in deep-dive-the-work-scope.md) 3. `` - Image with caption (used in README.md and introduction-to-impact-claims.md, 3 instances) Markdoc uses a similar `{% tagname %}` syntax but with a different closing convention: `{% /tagname %}` instead of `{% endtagname %}`. ## Markdoc Tag System Tags are defined in the markdoc/tags/ directory. Each tag needs: 1. A tag definition file (e.g., markdoc/tags/callout.markdoc.js) that specifies render component, allowed children, and attributes 2. A React component (e.g., components/Callout.js) that renders the HTML Example tag definition: ```js export const callout = { render: 'Callout', children: ['paragraph', 'tag', 'list'], attributes: { type: { type: String, default: 'info', matches: ['info', 'warning', 'danger', 'success'] } } }; ``` Tags are registered via markdoc/tags/index.js and wired to React components in _app.js. ## Acceptance Criteria - markdoc/tags/callout.markdoc.js exists with type attribute (info, warning, danger, success) - components/Callout.js renders a styled callout box with colored left border and background tint - markdoc/tags/columns.markdoc.js and markdoc/tags/column.markdoc.js exist - components/Columns.js renders a CSS flexbox/grid multi-column layout - components/Column.js renders individual column content - markdoc/tags/figure.markdoc.js exists as a self-closing tag with src, alt, caption attributes - components/Figure.js renders an image with optional caption - markdoc/tags/index.js exports all tags - All tags render correctly when used in .md files via the Markdoc pipeline

title: Epic 5: Styling and Visual Design
description:
## Summary
Create the CSS styling for the documentation site, covering typography, component styles (callouts, columns, figures, tables), layout, and responsive design.

## Context
This is a documentation site migrated from GitBook to Next.js + Markdoc. The React components (Callout, Columns, Column, Figure, Sidebar, Layout) are built in Epic 2 and Epic 4, but they need CSS styling to look polished.

## Required Styles

### Base Styles (styles/globals.css)
- CSS reset/normalize
- Typography: system font stack, comfortable line-height (1.6-1.7), proper heading hierarchy (h1-h6)
- Body max-width for content area (~800px)
- Links: colored, underlined on hover
- Inline code: background tint, border-radius, monospace font
- Code blocks: dark background, padding, horizontal scroll, monospace font. Consider adding prism-react-renderer for syntax highlighting (only 2 JSON blocks exist currently but SDK docs will grow).
- Blockquotes: left border, italic
- Horizontal rules: subtle divider
- Lists: proper indentation, spacing

### Table Styles
- Bordered cells with subtle borders
- Header row with bold text and slight background tint
- Alternating row backgrounds (zebra striping) optional
- Proper padding in cells
- Responsive: horizontal scroll on narrow screens
- Note: 9 files use standard Markdown tables

### Component Styles
- **Callout**: Colored left border (4px), light background tint, padding. Colors by type: info=blue, warning=yellow, danger=red, success=green. Optional icon per type.
- **Columns**: CSS flexbox, gap between columns, responsive (stack on mobile < 768px)
- **Column**: flex: 1 (equal width by default)
- **Figure**: Centered image, max-width: 100%, optional caption in smaller/italic text below

### Layout Styles
- **Sidebar**: Fixed/sticky position, 260px width, scrollable if content overflows, border-right divider
- **Main content**: margin-left to accommodate sidebar, padding
- **Header**: Site title, minimal height
- **Pagination**: Flex row with prev/next links at bottom of content
- **Mobile**: Sidebar hidden behind hamburger menu below 768px

## Acceptance Criteria
- All text content (headings, paragraphs, lists, code, tables) is well-styled and readable
- Callout boxes are visually distinct with colored borders and backgrounds per type
- Columns layout works on desktop and stacks on mobile
- Tables are bordered, padded, and readable
- Sidebar is fixed, scrollable, and collapses on mobile
- Site looks professional and clean (comparable to Stripe docs or GitBook quality)
- No unstyled/broken elements on any page
- Code blocks have syntax highlighting for at least JSON
